Award.AwardTitle: Modeling and Isotopes Link Mycorrhizal Fungi to Soil Carbon and Organic Nitrogen Use
Award.AbstractNarration:
Birch, willow, and other shrubs in the Arctic are increasing in response to warming at the expense of grasses and sedges. This increased shrub cover may enhance winter snow capture, increase winter soil temperatures, deepen summer soil thawing, and increase the release of old carbon and nitrogen. The increased flux of sugars from shrubs to shrub-associated symbiotic fungi (termed mycorrhizal fungi) could stimulate decomposition of thawing organic matter and release organic nitrogen for plant uptake previously locked up for millennia. This mycorrhizally-mediated priming of decomposition may influence carbon balances and nutrient availability for further shrub growth. To test this, researchers will use long-running experiments in Arctic Alaska that are examining plant responses to warming in different tundra types. Researchers will use natural levels of carbon and nitrogen isotopes to track the incorporation of new soil-derived organic nitrogen into shrubs and associated mycorrhizal fungi.
With the new methodologies developed, organic nitrogen use can be assessed across ecosystems. Models derived from planned measurements can then predict consequences of shrub expansion for ecosystem processes, such as soil energy balances, permafrost melting, and the release and cycling of old soil organic matter. Archived samples of fungi and plants from Alaska and across the Arctic will expand the temporal and geographic relevance of the studies. The project will provide education and research opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students. Researchers will also work with local high school teachers to use fungi as a tool to teach biology and to expand their work in outdoor classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Arctic is warming rapidly and the consequences of this warming on the vegetation, soils, and animals of the future Arctic are of intense interest. One possibility is that warming soils will release nutrients that could fuel plant growth and changes in arctic plants, particularly increases in arctic shrubs such as birch and willow. These shrubs rely on symbiotic (mycorrhizal) fungi linked to their roots to obtain nutrients from the soil, as those fungi possess strong enzymatic capabilities to access organic forms of nitrogen in the soil, such as amino acids.

Nitrogen is considered the primary limiting nutrient in tundra ecosystems. Thus, how nitrogen is obtained from the soil and delivered to plants is an important question in this warming response. In particular, the mycorrhizal fungi with which many plants associate could potentially obtain organic nitrogen from the soil and transfer part of it to their host plants in exchange for the energy subsidy of plant-derived sugars.

The project had several major goals:

1. to use natural abundance of radiocarbon to assess organic nitrogen assimilation by ectomycorrhizal fungi and by plants in the Arctic.

2. Use field fertilization and warming experiments at the Arctic LTER (Toolik) as probes of how specific components of these systems (e.g., plants of different functional types) responded when perturbed.

3. Use mammals as integrators of ecosystem-scale processes or properties, such as shifts in vegetation in response to climate or the relative abundance between sites of ectomycorrhizal fungi.

4. Develop models that explicitly incorporate the effects of organic nitrogen use and mycorrhizal fungi on ecosystem carbon and nitrogen cycling.

One study combined work on small mammals (arctic ground squirrels), plants, and mycorrhizal fungi. In arctic Alaska, plants without mycorrhizal symbionts such as arctic sedges did not assimilate old organic nitrogen from the soil, whereas ectomycorrhizal fungi did. Arctic ground squirrels that consumed mushrooms of mycorrhizal fungi proved to integrate the fungal-derived signal of soil organic nitrogen in their tissues, and such mushroom-eating small mammals may prove useful as integrators of soil processes.

Studies were also done in other parts of the Arctic. In the high arctic archipelago of Svalbard (Norway), reindeer diets were estimated from isotopic measurements on hair. The reindeer integrated plant responses to climate and global change over a 19-year period, 1994-2013. Sedges increased with warmer temperatures, and the rising carbon dioxide levels over this period enhanced plant photosynthesis and reduced plant photorespiration, a wasteful biochemical reaction. In a fungal survey from Svalbard, mainland Norway, and Denmark, the dependence on soil-derived organic nitrogen in colder climates appeared to increase and fungal carbon isotopes (13C:12C ratios) decreased later in the growing season, indicating the short residence time of fungal carbon before mushroom production. These Scandinavian fungi also demonstrated that their woody plant hosts responded to rising carbon dioxide levels with reduced photorespiration, as also deduced from Svalbard reindeer.

Fertilization and warming experiments at the Arctic Long-term Ecosystem Research (LTER) station in arctic Alaska were also used to study plant and fungal response. Fertilization appeared to decrease allocation by plants to mycorrhizal fungi, with ericaceous plants such as blueberries responding to nitrogen fertilization and ectomycorrhizal plants such as Betula nana (dwarf birch) responding to either nitrogen or phosphorus fertilization. Plants rooting at greater depth appeared less affected by fertilization.

We reviewed field studies that have assessed organic nitrogen uptake by plants in the Arctic and in boreal forests. We concluded that much of the estimated uptake is an artifact of the high concentrations of isotopically labeled amino acids that are generally applied in such studies, and furthermore concluded that the reported concentrations of amino acids in soil do not for the most part represent bioavailable concentrations, but rather reflect experimental artifacts arising from disturbance or reflect amino acids that are sequestered in micropores or otherwise unavailable for microbial uptake.

Currently, two papers have been published with support from this project, with three currently in review. In addition, a post-doctoral associate, four PhD students, and 12 undergraduate students participated in the research. Other outreach included leading fungal forays and evening lectures at the arctic research station and lecturing annually about diets and nutrition to high school students.
